      • resolver

        public ModuleProvider resolver(@Nullable
                               ArtModuleDependencyResolver resolver)
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Registers the given resolve with the module provider.

        The provider will use the given resolver when a module has unknown dependencies. Set the resolver to null to clear out the default resolver and only use registered modules.

        Specified by:
        resolver in interface ModuleProvider
        Parameters:

      • register

        public ModuleProvider register(@NonNull
                               @NonNull java.lang.Object module)
                        throws ModuleRegistrationException
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Registers the given module with the provider, but does not enable it.

        This is useful if you need to load multiple modules that depend upon each other and do not want to directly enable them.

        Make sure the class is annotated with @ArtModule or the registration will fail with an exception.

        If you want to directly load and enable your module, call ModuleProvider.enable(Object) instead. And if you don't have an instance of your module use the ModuleProvider.register(Class) method instead.

        Specified by:
        register in interface ModuleProvider
        Parameters:
        module - the module that should be registered
        Returns:
        this module provider
        Throws:
        ModuleRegistrationException - if the registration of the module failed, e.g. if no @ArtModule annotation is present on the class

      • register

        public ModuleProvider register(@NonNull
                               @NonNull java.lang.Class<?> moduleClass)
                        throws ModuleRegistrationException
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Registers the given class as a module with the provider.

        Use this if you do not have an instance of the module and one should be created for you. This could be the case if the module was loaded from a classpath search inside one of the module JAR files.

        The class must provide a parameterless public constructor or the module won't be registered. Also make sure it is annotated with @ArtModule or else the registration will fail also.

        Use ModuleProvider.register(Object) if you already have an instance of your module, e.g. it was loaded as a plugin.

        Specified by:
        register in interface ModuleProvider
        Parameters:
        moduleClass - the class of the module
        Returns:
        this module provider
        Throws:
        ModuleRegistrationException - if the registration or instance creation of the module failed, e.g. if no @ArtModule annotation is present on the class or no instance of the module could be created.

      • enable

        public ModuleProvider enable(@NonNull
                             @NonNull java.lang.Object module)
                      throws ModuleRegistrationException
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Loads the given module into the art-framework configuration instance and enables it.

        This will call any methods inside the module that are annotated with one of the On... annotations.

        Make sure the class is annotated with @ArtModule or the registration will fail with an exception.

        Specified by:
        enable in interface ModuleProvider
        Parameters:
        module - the module that should be loaded
        Returns:
        this module provider
        Throws:
        ModuleRegistrationException - if the registration of the module failed, e.g. if no @ArtModule annotation is present on the class or if one of the annotated methods encountered an exception.
        See Also:
        OnEnable, OnDisable, OnLoad

      • enable

        public ModuleProvider enable(@NonNull
                             @NonNull java.lang.Class<?> moduleClass)
                      throws ModuleRegistrationException
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Loads the given module into the art-framework configuration instance and enables it.

        Use this if you do not have an instance of the module and one should be created for you. This could be the case if the module was loaded from a classpath search inside one of the module JAR files.

        The class must provide a parameterless public constructor or the module won't be registered. Also make sure it is annotated with @ArtModule or else the registration will fail also.

        This will then call any methods inside the module that are annotated with one of the On... annotations.

        Use ModuleProvider.enable(Object) if you already have an instance of your module, e.g. it was loaded as a plugin.

        Specified by:
        enable in interface ModuleProvider
        Parameters:
        moduleClass - the class of the module
        Returns:
        this module provider
        Throws:
        ModuleRegistrationException - if the registration or instance creation of the module failed, e.g. if no @ArtModule annotation is present on the class, no instance of the module could be created or if one of the annotated methods encountered an exception.
        See Also:
        OnEnable, OnDisable, OnLoad

      • disable

        public ModuleProvider disable(@NonNull
                              @NonNull java.lang.Object module)
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Disabled the given module and unloads it from the art-framework configuration instance.

        Returns:

      • reload

        public ModuleProvider reload(@NonNull
                             @NonNull java.lang.Class<?> moduleClass)
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Reloads the module with the given class if it exists and is enabled.

        The module also must have a method tagged with the @OnReload annotation.

        Specified by:
        reload in interface ModuleProvider
        Parameters:
        moduleClass - the class of the module that should be reloaded
        Returns:
        this module provider

      • reloadAll

        public ModuleProvider reloadAll()
        Description copied from interface: ModuleProvider
        Reloads all enabled modules calling the tagged reload method if it is present.
        Specified by:
        reloadAll in interface ModuleProvider
        Returns:
        this module provider
